definitions: to give a new shape or form to something physical or malleable
to reorganize or restructure something such as an organization or approach
examples: The sculptor carefully reshaped the clay into a bird
The heat reshaped the plastic container into something unrecognizable
The company completely reshaped its marketing strategy last year
The crisis reshaped how we think about public health

definitions: to reorganize people in different positions especially in government or management
to shuffle playing cards again or mix items into a different order
examples: The prime minister decided to reshuffle the cabinet yesterday
The manager reshuffled the team to improve department efficiency
Please reshuffle the deck before we start the next game
The teacher reshuffled the seating chart every month

definitions: to live in a particular place as one's permanent home
to be present or exist in something as an inherent quality or characteristic
examples: They reside in a small village outside the city
The ambassador resides at the official residence downtown
The power to make laws resides with the parliament
The problem resides in the system's basic design

definitions: to voluntarily leave a job or position especially by formal notification
to accept something unpleasant that cannot be changed with patient submission
examples: The minister resigned from office after the scandal broke
She resigned her position to pursue other opportunities
He resigned himself to spending the weekend working overtime
They finally resigned themselves to the inevitable delay

definitions: to fight against or oppose something or someone with force or determination
to remain unchanged or undamaged by something harmful or destructive
to stop oneself from doing something despite wanting to do it
examples: The protesters continued to resist the new regulations
The army resisted the enemy advance for three days
This material resists water and stains effectively
The old building resisted the earthquake remarkably well
She couldn't resist buying the beautiful dress
He resisted the urge to check his phone

definitions: to find a solution to a problem or dispute through discussion or action
to make a firm decision to do something with strong determination
to separate something into constituent parts or analyze into components
examples: The committee resolved the dispute after hours of negotiation
We need to resolve this issue before moving forward
She resolved to exercise every morning without exception
The board resolved that changes were necessary immediately
The microscope can resolve individual cells in the tissue
The image slowly resolved into recognizable shapes

definitions: to produce or be filled with a deep reverberating sound or vibration
to evoke a feeling of shared emotion or understanding in someone
examples: The bass notes resonated through the concert hall walls
The bell resonated for several seconds after being struck
Her speech resonated deeply with the audience members present
That experience really resonates with my own childhood memories

definitions: to turn to something as a final option when other possibilities fail
to go to a place for relaxation recreation or vacation purposes
examples: They had to resort to emergency measures during the crisis
She resorted to shouting when no one would listen
Many tourists resort to the mountains during summer vacation
They resort to that beach town every year

definitions: to feel or show admiration and deference toward someone or something
to avoid interfering with or harming something by following rules or wishes
examples: Everyone respects her for her honesty and integrity
The students learned to respect their teachers' knowledge
Please respect the privacy of other hotel guests
All visitors must respect the park regulations strictly

definitions: to say or write something as an answer to a question or statement
to react to something with a particular action emotion or biological change
examples: She responded to the email within minutes of receiving it
The spokesperson responded that an investigation was underway
The patient responded well to the new treatment plan
Markets responded negatively to the announcement yesterday

definitions: to cease work or movement in order to relax or recover strength
to be placed or supported on something else as a foundation
to remain or be left in a specified condition or state
examples: She needs to rest after working twelve hours straight
The doctor advised him to rest for several days
The ladder rests against the wall very precariously
Her head rested gently on his shoulder
The final decision rests with the board of directors
The matter cannot rest there without further investigation

definitions: to start something again after it has stopped or been interrupted
to turn a machine or computer off and then on again
examples: We need to restart negotiations after the holiday break
The teacher restarted the lesson after the fire drill
Please restart your computer to apply the updates
The engine wouldn't restart after it stalled

definitions: to bring something back to its original condition through repair or renovation
to bring back a previous practice system or situation that existed before
to repair and clean a work of art or historic building professionally
examples: The team worked to restore the old mansion to its former glory
Exercise helped restore his health after the illness
The new government promised to restore democracy immediately
The company hopes to restore customer confidence soon
Experts carefully restored the Renaissance painting over two years
They restored the cathedral after the fire damage

definitions: to prevent someone from doing something by holding them back physically
to control or limit emotions actions or behavior through conscious effort
examples: Security guards had to restrain the angry customer
The nurse gently restrained the patient during the procedure
She had to restrain her anger during the meeting
He restrained himself from making a sarcastic comment

definitions: to put a limit on the size amount or range of something
to limit someone's actions or movements especially through rules or physical barriers
examples: The new law restricts the use of plastic bags
We need to restrict our spending this month
The hospital restricts visiting hours to protect patients
Access is restricted to authorized personnel only

definitions: to organize a company or system differently especially to improve efficiency
to arrange the terms of debt or financial obligations in a new way
examples: The company restructured its operations to reduce costs significantly
They plan to restructure the department next quarter
The bank agreed to restructure the loan payment schedule
Several countries had to restructure their national debt

definitions: to occur or follow as a consequence or effect of something
to have a specified outcome or end in a particular way
examples: The accident resulted from careless driving in bad weather
Higher prices resulted in decreased customer demand
The negotiations resulted in a comprehensive trade agreement
Their efforts resulted in significant improvements

definitions: to begin again or continue after a pause or interruption
to return to a previous position activity or state after stopping
examples: The meeting will resume after the lunch break ends
Play resumed when the rain finally stopped
She resumed her studies after taking a year off
Normal service will resume tomorrow morning

definitions: to put a new surface on something especially a road or sports court
to appear again after being hidden absent or forgotten for a time
examples: The city will resurface Main Street next month
They resurfaced the tennis courts before the tournament
Old memories resurfaced during the class reunion yesterday
The scandal resurfaced just before the election

definitions: to bring someone back to life from the dead literally or figuratively
to bring back into use or popularity something that had been forgotten
examples: According to the story, the prophet resurrected the dead child
The medical team managed to resurrect him after cardiac arrest
The studio wants to resurrect the old TV series
They resurrected an ancient tradition for the festival

definitions: to revive someone from unconsciousness or apparent death using medical procedures
to make something active successful or viable again after decline
examples: Paramedics successfully resuscitated the drowning victim at the beach
The doctor resuscitated the patient using CPR techniques
The new CEO hopes to resuscitate the failing company
They're trying to resuscitate interest in classical music

definitions: to sell goods directly to consumers in small quantities rather than wholesale
to relate or repeat gossip or stories especially in detail
examples: The store retails designer clothing at affordable prices
This product retails for fifty dollars nationwide
She loves to retail the latest office gossip
He retailed every detail of the conversation

definitions: to continue to have or keep something in one's possession or control
to keep information in one's memory over a period of time
to employ someone especially a lawyer by paying a preliminary fee
examples: The company retained ownership of the patent rights
She retained her maiden name after getting married
Students often struggle to retain complex information
He retains everything he reads with amazing clarity
They retained a lawyer to handle the case
We retained a consultant for the project

definitions: to take an exam or test again after failing or wanting improvement
to take back control of a place that was previously lost
to take a photograph or record a scene again for better results
examples: She had to retake the driving test three times
Students can retake the exam next semester
The army retook the city after months of fighting
They managed to retake control of the company
Let's retake that photo with better lighting
The director decided to retake the entire scene

definitions: to attack or harm someone in response to being attacked or harmed
to take action against someone in response to their negative actions
examples: The country threatened to retaliate against economic sanctions
The army retaliated swiftly after the surprise attack
She retaliated by spreading rumors about her rival
Workers retaliated against the pay cuts with strikes

definitions: to slow down or delay the progress movement or development of something
to cause something to develop or occur more slowly than normal
examples: Cold weather significantly retards plant growth in spring
The treatment retards the progression of the disease
Lack of funding has retarded scientific research considerably
Poor nutrition can retard a child's physical development

definitions: to think carefully about something again especially with the possibility of changing
to consider something from a new or different perspective
examples: We need to rethink our approach to this problem
The company is rethinking its expansion plans completely
Scientists are rethinking basic assumptions about evolution
It's time to rethink how we teach mathematics

definitions: to leave one's job and stop working usually because of reaching a certain age
to withdraw from a race competition or active participation in something
to go to bed or to one's private room especially for the night
examples: She plans to retire when she turns sixty-five
He retired from teaching after forty years
The injured player had to retire from the match
The ship was retired from active service
The guests retired to their rooms after dinner
He usually retires early on weekday nights

definitions: to say something sharp or witty in answer to a remark or accusation
to heat a substance in a retort vessel for chemical processing
examples: She retorted that his argument made no sense whatsoever
He retorted angrily when criticized about his work
The chemist retorted the mixture at high temperature
They retorted the ore to extract the mercury

definitions: to go back over the same route or path that one has already traveled
to discover or describe the sequence of past events or actions
examples: We retraced our steps to find the lost keys
The hikers had to retrace their path down the mountain
Detectives retraced the victim's movements before the crime
The historian retraced the explorer's journey through archives

definitions: to withdraw or take back a statement admission or accusation
to draw back or pull in a part of the body or a mechanical part
examples: The newspaper retracted the story after discovering errors
She refused to retract her controversial statement
The cat retracted its claws after the threat passed
The landing gear retracts automatically after takeoff

definitions: to withdraw troops or forces from enemy engagement or dangerous position
to move back or withdraw from a difficult or uncomfortable situation
to go to a quiet or secluded place for privacy rest or meditation
examples: The army retreated after suffering heavy casualties
Enemy forces retreated across the river at dawn
She retreated from the argument to avoid conflict
The tide retreated leaving shells on the beach
They retreated to a cabin in the mountains
The monks retreat for meditation every morning

definitions: to get something back from a place where it was left or stored
to find and bring back something especially for a dog fetching game
to find and extract stored information from a computer system
examples: She retrieved her luggage from the airport carousel
Can you retrieve my coat from the car?
The dog eagerly retrieved the tennis ball
The hunting dog retrieved the duck from the lake
The system quickly retrieves data from the database
I can't retrieve the deleted files anymore

definitions: to add new parts or equipment to something that did not have them originally
to modify an existing building or system to include modern improvements
examples: They retrofitted the old factory with solar panels
The airline retrofitted its planes with new safety equipment
Many buildings were retrofitted to meet earthquake standards
We retrofitted the house with energy-efficient windows

definitions: to move backward or in a reverse direction especially in astronomy
to revert to an earlier and usually worse or less developed state
examples: Mercury appears to retrograde three times each year
The planet retrogrades through the zodiac signs
The patient's condition began to retrograde unexpectedly
Society seems to retrograde rather than progress

definitions: to think about or review past events with the advantage of later knowledge
examples: Looking back, I retrospect on all the mistakes I made
We often retrospect about our college days together

definitions: to make another attempt at something that previously failed or was unsuccessful
to try a legal case again in court after an appeal or mistrial
examples: Please retry entering your password if it fails
The system will automatically retry the connection
The court decided to retry the case next month
The prosecutor wants to retry the defendant

definitions: to come or go back to a place person or activity after absence
to give put or send something back to its previous place or owner
to yield or produce profit or interest as an investment
examples: She returns home every evening at six o'clock
The birds return to the same nesting site annually
Please return the library books by Friday afternoon
He returned the defective product for a refund
The investment returns eight percent interest per year
These bonds return a steady income stream

definitions: to bring people or things together again after a period of separation
to come together again after being apart for some time
examples: The agency works to reunite families separated by war
They reunited the lost dog with its owner
The band reunited for a special anniversary concert
Old classmates reunited at the twenty-year reunion

definitions: to use something again especially after processing or for a different purpose
examples: We should reuse plastic containers whenever possible
The company reuses shipping boxes to reduce waste

definitions: to increase the speed of an engine especially while the vehicle is stationary
to make someone excited or increase the intensity of activity
examples: He revved the motorcycle engine at the traffic light
Don't rev the engine too hard when it's cold
The coach revved up the team before the game
The crowd was revved up for the concert

definitions: to give something a new and improved form structure or appearance
examples: The company completely revamped its website last month
They plan to revamp the entire curriculum next year

definitions: to make something visible that was previously hidden or covered
to make known information that was previously secret or unknown
examples: The curtain lifted to reveal the stage set
Removing the paint revealed the original wood underneath
The investigation revealed widespread corruption in the department
She finally revealed her true feelings about the situation

definitions: to enjoy oneself in a lively and noisy way especially with drinking and dancing
to take great pleasure or delight in something
examples: The students reveled until dawn after graduation
The crowd reveled in the streets after the victory
She revels in the attention from her fans
He reveled in his newfound freedom

definitions: to inflict harm or injury in return for a wrong suffered at someone's hands
examples: He swore to revenge his brother's death someday
She revenged herself on those who had betrayed her

definitions: to feel deep respect admiration or awe for someone or something
examples: The students revere their wise and patient teacher
Many cultures revere their ancestors and traditions

definitions: to regard or treat someone or something with deep respect and honor
examples: The congregation reverenced the sacred texts with great care
They reverenced the memory of their fallen heroes

definitions: to turn something completely around to face the opposite direction
to change something to its complete opposite or contrary state
to move backward especially when driving a vehicle
examples: She reversed the jacket to show the other side
The mirror reverses the image you see
The court reversed its earlier decision on appeal
The new policy reverses years of environmental progress
He carefully reversed the car into the parking space
Can you reverse out of the driveway?

definitions: to return to a previous state practice subject or way of behaving
examples: The software will revert to default settings automatically
After treatment, the cells reverted to their normal state

definitions: to examine or consider something again especially to check or improve it
to write a critical assessment of a book film or performance
to study material again especially in preparation for an examination
examples: The committee will review all applications next week
Please review the contract before signing it
She reviews books for the literary magazine
Critics reviewed the play very favorably
Students should review their notes before the test
Let's review what we learned yesterday
